thread.title: Big Ten East Division Power Rankings: J.T. Barrett to Lead the Buckeyes Again
thread.title_full: Big Ten East Division Power Rankings: J.T. Barrett to Lead the Buckeyes Again

title: Big Ten East Division Power Rankings: J.T. Barrett to Lead the Buckeyes Again
text:
Get Sports Alerts 
23 Oct 2015 01:31 PM EST 
-by Daniel Mogollon, Staff Writer; Image: Ohio State sophomore quarterback J.T. Barrett. (Image Source: Andrew Weber/Getty Images) 
Big Ten East division power rankings following Week 7: 
(1) Ohio State Buckeyes (1); Record: 7-0 (3-0) 
Last Week: Won vs. Penn State 38-10 
With J.T. Barrett getting more and more playing time as the season progresses, the Buckeyes went to the ground game against PSU, rushing for 315 yards on 50 carries (vs. 19 pass attempts) as a team (including -16 yards on 4 “rushes” by Cardale Jones ). Barrett is brilliant running the read option, particularly in the red zone and he was incredibly efficient on Saturday night completing all four of his passes, including two TDs, while rushing for 102 yards and two more scores on just 11 carries. That’s why it came as no surprise that Urban Meyer finally named him the starting QB. 
Coming Up: 10/24: @ Rutgers; 10/31: Idle 
(2) Michigan State Spartans; Record (3): 7-0 (3-0) 
Last Week: Won @ Michigan 27-23 
That was maybe the most-improbably finish I’ve ever seen. Saturday’s win over Michigan in Ann Arbor helps keep the Spartans in the playoff race in that they remain undefeated however that doesn’t mean they are a playoff-caliber team. That remains to be seen. Neither team was able to run the ball and while QB Connor Cook completed fewer than half his passes his 328 passing yards kept Sparty in the game and allowed them to take advantage of Michigan’s last-minute blunder. 
Coming Up: 10/24: vs. Indiana; 10/31: Idle 
(3) Michigan Wolverines (2); Record: 5-2 (2-1) 
Last Week: Lost vs. Michigan State 27-23 
Wow. Just. Wow. The muffed snap-turned-TD by punter Blake O’Neill is simply unfathomable. It can’t happen except it did. Make no mistake…that final play cost the Wolverines the contest but that doesn’t mean the Maize and Blue played a perfect game. There were too many breakdowns in the pass defense—four plays of 27-plus yards—and the rushing attack regressed ( De’Veon Smith was held to 46 yards on 19 carries) against a tougher front seven than they’ve faced during their winning streak. 
Coming Up: 10/24: Idle; 10/31: @ Minnesota 
(4) Penn State Nittany Lions (4); Record: 5-2 (2-1) 
Last Week: Lost @ Ohio State 38-10 
Youngsters, sophomore WR Chris Godwin and freshman RB Saquon Barkley , had strong efforts, but their lack of run D and inability to extend (1 of 12 on 3 rd downs; 0 of 2 on fourth downs) or finish drives cost them in the end. Barkley (26 carries, 194 yards) is the type of difference maker the Nittany Lions have lacked in the backfield and if he can stay healthy maybe PSU can surprise some people before it’s all said and done. This week’s game in Baltimore is an opportunity to get on a roll. 
Coming Up: 10/24: vs. Maryland; 10/31: vs. Illinois 
(5) Rutgers Scarlet Knights (5); Record: 3-3 (1-2) 
Last Week: Won @ Indiana 55-52 
Senior WR Leonte Carroo had his second-straight three-touchdown game, however he was injured (game-time decision for this week) on his final trip to the painted area, which meant the Scarlet Knights would have to overcome a 19-point fourth-quarter deficit without their best player. No problem. A defensive score pulled RU to within 13-points and their balanced offense won the day in the end. QB Chris Laviano (386 yards) threw three TD passes and RB Robert Martin (124 yards) ran for three scores as Rutgers pulled back to .500 with their first B1G win of the season. 
Coming Up: 10/24: vs. Ohio State; 10/31: @ Wisconsin 
(6) Indiana Hoosiers (6); Record: 4-3 (0-3) 
Last Week: Lost vs. Rutgers 55-52 
Nationally and around the Big Ten, Michigan’s loss was the one that got the most headlines, but the Hoosiers suffered a pretty brutal defeat of their own in Bloomington. After scoring four touchdowns in the first 10 minutes of the third quarter, the Hoosiers led 52-27 and presumably were well on their way to their fifth win of the season. QB Nate Sudfeld (464 yards, 4 TDs) was back and so was IU’s explosive attack. However, things imploded after that and IU was outscored 28-0 over the final 20 minutes as their D failed them yet again. 
Coming Up: 10/24: @ Michigan State; 10/31: Idle 
(7) Maryland Terrapins (7); Record: 2-4 (0-2) 
Last Week: Idle 
The Mike Locksley era begins on Saturday against rival PSU, but the changes have already begun in College Park. Locksley has moved sophomore Shane Cockerille from fullback back to quarterback. Perry Hills remains the starter, but the way Hills and Caleb Rowe have performed I wouldn’t be surprised to see Cockerille under center at some point this season. 
Coming Up: 10/24: vs. Penn State; 10/31: @ Iowa 
Daniel Mogollon is a member of the Pro Football Writers of America and the Football Writers Association of America. He is also a voter for the Thorpe and the Rotary Lombardi Award, as well as the Latino Sports MVP Awards. You can reach him via email: danmogollon@gmail.com .
